												Although pitched as a Zelda parody, dismissing Ittle Dew as such would be doing it a disservice. While the delightful art style and fantastic soundtrack both pay homage to the classic series, the similarities in actual gameplay are rather cursory and it turns out that's a good thing.The emphasis here is entirely on the puzzles, more specifically, block puzzles. You'll spend nearly your entire stay on the island pushing, freezing, and teleporting blocks and enemies around, flipping switches and ultimately opening a ton of chests and doors on your quest for treasure. As the sole focus of the adventure the quality of the puzzles is paramount, and fortunately they happen to be supremely well designed and satisfying to solve, rarely crossing the line into overly hard nor easy. They provide an entertaining challenge as well as a bit of replayability with several different paths available for completing the game, something that's rarely seen in this genre.All of this combined with the clever boss fights, tongue in cheek humor, and outstanding presentation add up to a very short but (technical hiccups aside) immensely enjoyable game from start to finish. Don't make the mistake of taking Ittle Dew at face value, for it has more than enough heart to breakaway from it's inspiration, and should not be missed!

												On the surface Ittle Dew looks like a Zelda clone. Playing as a blonde in a green tunic with a sword (or stick), stuck on an island with a flying friend and top down gameplay doesn't help make it not look like a Zelda clone. That's the flavor of the game. Is it Zelda? No, but it'll do (Ittle Do). This game is slightly different than a Zelda clone because it is a push block puzzle game with a few enemies and deviations from push block puzzles. There are a few items and you start with a stick that you can use to light on fire, then melt ice blocks, set off bombs and so on. Eventually you'll move to a flaming sword to do what a flaming stick can, a magical teleportation wand that allows you to set a block, use the wand and have the enemy or object appear where you set the block. Finally, you'll get an ice wand to freeze enemies, blocks, put out fire and even make walls reflect projectiles like your teleportation staff. You can tell a lot of work went into making the items as not just items to solve puzzles, but combat items as well. You can use the teleporation block to set a block under you, step off and if an enemy is on it, the enemy will fly off screen. You can set a block, push it onto spikes, then use the teleportation wand to teleport the enemy into the block on the spikes, killing them that way. Even though it is disguised as Zelda, I feel like the game could have been made in RPG Maker.All of the items and weapons are bound to buttons on the X-Box controller which is nice, you can use everything at once without having to visit a menu. There are no deaths in this game, so much as there are room restarts. When you die, you just reset whatever room you were in with full health. Rooms including sections of the overworld map. There is no consequence, making it a very easy for kids game. Each room has a hint sign or two and if you need even more help, you can hit the left button to have your fluttering fox friend give you a hint. There is even a nice little map too showing you where treasures and doors are (unlocked and locked).This is an enjoyable game even if its quick and simple when compared to Zelda. There is a good diverse array of enemies with different ways to take them out. The art style is charming, there is plenty of exploration and a slightly open world go where you want feel. The art style, happy nature, hints and ease of puzzles makes me feel this game is better for kids. Give it a go, its fun for a few brief hours until you complete it in one or two sittings. The game is so brief, there are achievements for beating it under 3 hours and completing it under 15 minutes.Ittle Dew is a good stepping stone for this developer to make a grander Zelda like game.

												The generally accepted reason for why there aren’t more games like The Legend Of Zelda is that they’re just too hard to make. Ocarina Of Time is still widely accepted as the best game ever made, but that in itself implies that its creation was not a trivial task. There have been attempts to copy the formula, from early titles like Golden Axe Warrior through to Alundra, 3D Dot Game Heroes, and Ōkami, but not only are these efforts rare but they’ve generally been commercial failures.That is likely to be the real reason for the lack of similar games, but such market realities are not something that indie developers generally worry about. Which is good because, despite a few caveats, Ittle Dew is one of the most enjoyable Zelda-a-likes we’ve played in years.Despite what it may look like Ittle Dew is not a straight clone, but it does have perhaps the most legitimate excuse for copying another game: comedy. Ittle Dew isn’t just a love letter to the Zelda games it’s also a parody of them, and its spunky heroine Ittle and her Navi stand-in Tippsie (a wonderfully cynical magic fox) gently poke fun at the series’ specific peculiarities and those of gaming in general.Tippsie in particular is hilarious, as she reacts with varying degrees of disgust to ordinary Zelda tropes, such as Ittle eating a heart to get more health to her quaffing potions when she’s not looking. Joking about smashing pots and what enemies do all day as they stand around in lonely dungeons may seem like obvious targets, but as we’ve often lamented games are strangely reticent to ever poke fun at their sillier traditions.The jovial mood is enhanced further by the wonderful visuals, but despite the art style being very different from any official Zelda game overall Ittle Dew still ends up looking lawyer-worryingly similar. The game is scheduled for release on Wii U later in the year though so we assume that Nintendo gets the joke as well.Ittle has a much more mercenary approach to her explorations than Link, happily stuffing her pockets with treasure as she goes about adventuring. Even the artefact she’s trying to obtain from a nearby castle is only to bribe a shopkeeper to build her a ship to get home. Although he does at least offer to sell her three items vital to her mission: a fire sword, an ice wand, and a portal-creating magic wand.Unusually for a Zelda game these are the only three items in the whole game, which is certainly a bold choice. But despite all the puzzles being solved using only one or more of the items it’s disappointing that the meat of most of them still revolves around pushing blocks and hitting switches. In the traditional manner there are torches and bombs to be lit, pressure pads to stand on, and doors to unlock. The puzzles might not be very imaginative but they are well designed and often have multiple solutions. You can even beat the entire game using any random combination of just two of the items. Some of the puzzles are very hard but the game isn’t interested in punishing you, only challenging you, and there’s a wide range of helpful hints given out by Tippsie.The dungeon-like areas are very much the focus of the game and although there are overworld areas they’re smaller and less interactive than real Zelda games. The combat is also significantly less interesting, being barely any more nuanced than the original NES game and offering zero reward beyond extra health. The bosses are a mostly decent bunch though and also get some of the best lines.Ittle Dew is rather short, at around three to four hours, although you’ll need much longer to collect everything and beat the optional Master Cave (the only truly difficult challenge in the whole thing). But for only a tenner you get a download that is not only fun but funny – a game that is amusingly self-aware but uses this as a means to enhance the experience and not just make excuses for it.Recommended

												I give this game a very cautious recommendation.I picked it up because I'm a huge Zelda fan, and it was on sale at the time. The gameplay is similar to a 2D Zelda in many regards in that you explore, fight, and solve puzzles using your trusty stick/sword and items that you gain throughout your adventure. So yes, there are a lot of familiar elements here if you like these kinds of games.That said, it doesn't PLAY like a Zelda game. That's not necessarily a bad thing depending on why you enjoy these games in the first place. Whereas Zelda has very tight, simple combat and excellent monster design, it becomes apparent soon after starting this game that combat is not the main focus. Ittle's stick has a short range and some enemies do not suffer knockback when hit. There are also not many enemies with unique weaknesses. Most of them are a simple hack n' slash affair.Where this game truly shines is in the puzzle department. I would even say that this game is more of a puzzle game than a 2D adventure game, because the world is compact and filled to the brim with puzzles. Many of them are actually challenging! I literally spent hours in the Master Cave, an optional dungeon filled with the toughest puzzles that this game has to offer, because the puzzles were so difficult and I was determined to solve them without a guide. Though I felt like ripping my hair out at the time, solving these complex puzzles was a rewarding experience in and of itself, unlike in Zelda dungeons where it sometimes feels like puzzles are just there to pad the game out.This is a short game, and there are only three items (besides the default stick) that you can obtain. The twist is that these items work together to help you solve puzzles and traverse the main dungeon. For instance, you can combine the portal wand and the ice rod to create an ice block that warps you to the other side of the room. This part of the game was handled ingeniously. There are so many things you can do with these three items and the objects in your environment. There are also multiple ways that you can beat the game, and you don't even need all of the items to do it. Pretty cool!As mentioned, this game is short. If you skipped the Master Cave, it would likely take you about 3-5 hours on your first attempt. The replay value comes from finding out different ways to beat the game using different combinations of items. The game is also uniformly hilarious and aware of its genre. Even the credit sequence is funny.TL;DR - This is more of a puzzle game than a 2D adventure game. If you like puzzles, you will probably like it.

												Ittle Dew is not only a clever name, but a very clever game. It takes Zelda's block pushing, torch lighting, and enemy managing puzzles to a point where they actually take some thought. 												Ittle Dew is a little game that stands somewhere between Zelda and Sokoban, with a very humorous tone, and featuring friendly game design, with aspects that can be appreciated by pretty much everyone.From casual playthroughs, so rock-hard puzzles and 15 minutes speedruns... it's got it all! It's weird, but it's very nice to see how almost every aspect of this game seems to just fit it and provide a great experience, despite its apparent simplicity!PresentationUndoubtedly, one of its strongest aspects, especially at first. The cartoon-y artstyle is very well done, with a pleasant color scheme, very clean, with added lighting effects modernising its look, somewhat. The highlight here for me, though, is the character design. Everyone looks unique, is a clumsy and silly way, and with their own backstory to support them. It's pretty good! Another detail I liked is how every line moves slightly, making everything seem more alive.The music and sound-effects didn't standout out too much for me, but fit nicely with the rest of the presentation, and it wasn't bad by any means! Just didn't seem to carry the experience, for me.I also found the writting to be funny at times, and it just gave the game a very light-hearted and self-aware tone the whole way through. Ranging from the dialogues with your health-potion drunk companion, to the enemies' entrances and the mocking signposts spread around, everything had something to make fun of.How's the game structured?Very much like a Zelda game, actually. You have an island to explore, and go through several dungeons to beat it. There is also some exploration done outside the main and tutorial dungeons.Near the beginning of the game, you'll find a shop. The shopkeeper tells you he can give you a raft to escape the island, if you get him the artifact in the castle. And off you go. He also has 3 items to sell. You'll find the gold for it in the castle. The game's puzzles revolve around these 3 items: you'll have to combine their abilities in very varied ways to solve the puzzles.The castle has many shortcuts, that you can take by solving much harder puzzles. If you're stuck, you may as well try another way, or go buy another item. There are many different ways of making progress, too!The castle puzzles are pretty straighforward, though, so anyone can safely play it without fearing getting frustrated.Outside the castle, though, there are other smaller dungeon, with harder puzzles. These usually contain Cards with the game's characters. These are merely collectibles, but they're pretty charming too. The puzzles there can also hint at some mechanics you may have not learned throw the tutorial puzzles. As a segue, when you have enough gold, you can take one of several portals spread around the castle to fast travel. When you buy an item, you'll be catapulted into another part of the island. These are the tutorial areas. Your items are all stored near the shop, and you'll have to beat the dungeon only with your newfound item. With this, you'll learn how the item works well enough, and do that through play! I think it's a nice way of doing it.These dungeons also contain several paths and shortcuts. One important thing is that you'll never be able to leave the cave while missing important items. When you leave the dungeon, it will be sealed, but you can rest assured that you haven't missed anything important. This is also told to you after your first dungeon, in a sign post. The placing of that was very elegant: since there are multiple paths, it's very likely that you'll miss part of the map, and become worried after leaving the dungeon. Right when you're worrying about it, the signpost clarifies it for you.There are many places like this in the game, making tutorialisation nicely paced. Information is often delivered at the right moment!I think that about covers it.General MechanicsThis game has both combat and puzzles, although the focus is mainly on the puzzles. There are also some Boss Fights, most of which are more puzzle-driven than combat, although both blend rather nicely, items being multi-purposed.The combat is very straightforward. Your basic attack attacks the tile in front of you. There are also projectiles attacks. There are several different enemies, some that attack only in front of them, some have projectiles, etc. Different enemies require different approaches. Also, they'll respawn each time you enter the room, but it's never a problem as they're easy to avoid. Some puzzles also reset, but only when the initial conditions are necessary for you to solve another puzzle in the room (or perhaps to use a shortcut).The only problem I've had with the combat, is how the movement is a bit floaty, and there's a lack of knock-back with some enemies. The enemies often drop hearts to replenish your health, and the game is overall not punishing in the least, so it's not too big of an issue. Lack of PunishmentThat's mostly a good thing, but it sometimes holds the player's hand too much. For example, Boss fights have 3-5 phases, and there's usually a checkpoint between each. I've found that mostly unnecessary, taking the little challenge that they provided. I think boss fights should still be a threat!On the other hand, each time you die, you'll simply reset the room, but never lose progress, or collectibles at all. That's a very welcome thing! It's always annoying to do 4-5 rooms again when you die, or lose progress over a simple miss-step.The puzzles are basically Sokoban, with a few twists. You have 3 items: a Flaming Sword, a Freezing Wand, and a Teleporting Wand.The sword can set bombs on fire, to explode after a few seconds. The Freezing Wand can freeze enemies and blocks (making them very slippery when you push them, and also breakable), and can also freeze a wall, making it reflective.The Teleporting Wand can create a Green block anywhere. If you hit bombs or enemies with the projectile, they'll teleport over to that block. This is basically all you need to know.You combine these techniques with some more subtle quirks to the tiles and timing, and you can be faced with some evil difficult puzzles.Difficulty.Ittle Dew sets its casual from its hardcore puzzlesUsually, to beat the game, you have some fairly easy puzzles. To collect the cards, it's a different matter (although mostly doable). There's a final dungeon with 12 puzzles however, that is really hard! At least for someone inexperienced in Sokoban. I often had to peek into a walkthrough, and was constantly surprised with a new way of combining my items.Precision and Perfection rather than simply solving a puzzleThe problem is that some of these puzzles required extremely precise timing, with the game's controls don't provide very well, in my opinion. Also, these puzzles constantly made you restart at every wrong move. A time rewinding mechanic would be welcome, even if just on this cave. I had to restart these puzzles many times, making it a bit too frustrating. It wasn't just a puzzle to solve, it was something that heavily relied on execution, which I'm not a fan of.Then again, these were completely optional! And the game warned you that they were hard. If you complete it, you'll get some more cards, and also Development info, which is very cool!H.Mention: The castle can be solved with ANY combination of 2 items. I'm very impressed with this! The castle is so nicely designed that you can beat it with any combination of the two items, and the game aknowledges that with achievements. Also for cards, speed, etc.There are many ways of playing Ittle Dew, which is why I think it's a neatly designed game. Many ways that tie together brilliantly!Full Recommendation. Also, check Card City Nights!

												Preface: Be advised that this is not a "Zelda clone", but it does fall into the "puzzle dungeon" genre. It leans heavily into complex single-room puzzles with minimal combat. Contrast this with: Zelda's simpler, but multi-room puzzles, with casual-but-competent combat; and Darksiders' more refined combat and more focus on platforming.Novel and fresh take on an abused and neglected genre.Some highlights of particularly strong game design:* Each puzzle feels fresh. Particularly impressive given the amount of them* Comedic elements are light and witty, without trying to steal focus from the experience* Difficulty curve is smooth, with a good pacing of optional mini-puzzles along a parallel difficulty curve* At end of game, meaningful replay value in the form of multiple "low %" completion routes are made clear to the player* Optional end-dungeon "Master Cave" adds a new level of complexity to the fundamentals* Game intentionally avoids putting rewards in places that can be missed* No meaningful padding or filler, all content is quickly reachable from the center of the world* Death (though an extremely rare occurence as hazards are not the focus of the game) is not punishing, and just throws the player back at the start of the current room with minimal delay* I'll say it: better puzzle and dungeon design than any Zelda game. Puzzle elements are clearly identifiable, and multi-room puzzles are EXTREMELY rare (and when present, are simply that a room transition is one-way, which is always reasonably obvious)Some nitpicks to improve on:* Zelda Link to the Past has a superior melee attack, in that it hits in a wide arc. Ittle Dew's feels clunky in comparison. Thankfully, combat is not a focus for the vast majority of the game. But...* Final boss has a very "twitch action-game" phase when compared to the rest of the game, and thus unfairly gates players to completion by requiring a skillset they didn't sign up for, and the game didn't ramp them up to* "Master Cave" boss is devoid of puzzle elements entirely, and REALLY feels out of place in the game as a resultI would consider this game to be mandatory reference material for all developers in the "puzzle dungeon" genre.

I whole-heartedly recommend Ittle Dew. I have played it several times and I intend to come back to it more. It is well worth what you pay for it.Ittle Dew is a single-player game which at first glance is very similar to the old NES and SNES Zelda games. That is accurate, but there is a lot more to it.If you play for even a small amount of time, you will notice that Ittle Dew has a great irreverent style of humor which is enhanced by the lovable characters, and the mix of puzzle and combat gameplay suits it perfectly. There is very little fluff - by which I mean you will use the same puzzle elements over again, but in increasingly clever and novel ways. It is clear that the developers (Ludosity) took great care in crafting their game and distilling it down to a small, but densely packed experience that conveys constant quality.There are five boss fights in the game, of which three, including the final boss, are required to beat the main story. A fourth is required to gain all of the items. Each of the three dungeon bosses have specific mechanics which require you to use your new dungeon item as you have learned in the preceding area, creating a diverse experience that never gets tedious. There is also a fifth (tough) boss that is completely optional.Aside from the main story, there is an optional 'Master Cave' with twelve puzzles. They begin slightly more difficult than what you have done to beat the main story, but the difficulty ramps up quickly and some will leave you thinking for a long time before you can beat them. I was amazed at how clever some of the solutions were.If you haven't already, I recommend watching the trailer on the Steam Page - it will show you a good sample of the humor and puzzles you can expect.

												Ittle Dew is a 2D puzzle adventure game. Basically, it's like a 2D Legend of Zelda game with a heavy focus on the puzzles. You're washed up on a mysterious island and, as any good adventurer does, you start to adventure. It's pretty straightforward in terms of adventuring. You go from dungeon to dungeon as they become available to you, work on puzzles with the dungeons in order to complete them, and then receive items to help you progress further. Upon getting an item, you generally are sent to a new area without the other items, forcing you to get acquainted with the new item and its uses before being able to combine the uses of all your items. There are a few optional shortcuts and slightly hidden puzzles you can go after, which is nice for even more puzzle solving. It is also entire possible to complete the game without getting all of the items. You can beat it with a few combinations of a few items. These are reflected in the achivements, but... I'll be honest, I had enough trouble with the main game using everything. There's also some funny little dialogues going on in parts of the game which give it some life and keep things from getting too harsh on your brain. Almost like little rewards for continuing. And there are boss fights which will give some action to your problem solving skills. A nice blend for the game.There are a few downsides though, as all games have. One is that the game is rather short. Most of the playtime here will be from getting stuck on tricky puzzles. There's not much adventuring, as most of the places you go to are rather straightforward and without missable secrets. Even the optional puzzles are pretty easy to find. So I guess there could've been more adventure for my taste. Also, the combat is a little rough. It just feels a bit stiff and non responsive. There's less focus on it, but still, a little more fluidity might have been nice. Not a big deal, though. You can adjust. There were some pretty interesting puzzles, some involving good timing, but the game doesn't do a great job of teaching you the timing based techniques used later in the game. Also, there's an awful lot of block puzzles, so... if you don't like those... stay away.Overall, it's a pretty cool game. Is it worth the ten dollar price tag? Well, if you're a Zelda fan or a puzzle fan, yes. It's definitely worth checking out. For others? Possibly wait for a sale, or just give it a shot. It's a decent price for what you get. It has some neat sound and a fun art style. The music went well the the mood. It's definitely something anyone could enjoy, but recommended for only the Zelda fans or puzzle crowd, I'd say. If you're looking for more adventure, it may not be your cup of tea. And I must say that, even though it is a bit on the short side, it doesn't FEEL short. It feels like a full game, and that's where it counts. I'd give Ittle Dew 7/10. Good, solid game, but geared more towards the puzzle minded for sure.

												With the sequel confirmed and on the way, getting into Ittle Dew now is the perfect time. I had always meant to play this game but only now did I ever give it the chance. Maybe it was the Adventure Time style and humor that put me off, leading me to believe this game would be a nonsensical game without any logic. It is nosensical, in a good way, but the puzzles and gameplay are finely crafted with various solutions in an otherwise illogical adventure. Wake up, Adventurer. The story for Ittle Dew is simple: Beat things up and solve puzzles. And then you have weirdo, meta characters and conversations that take slight jabs at the game itself. The interactions with Tippsie (the flying fox) and Ittle are my favorite bits in the game, mostly because of how cynical and arrogant Tippsie comes off. If you do like the wierdness humor of Adventure Time or Regular Show, then you'll probably find the other characters entertaining. I had one or two laughs as I liked the small world of the game, but I didn't find anything too interesting or memorable.What Can You Dew?Where the story and the characters were lacking, the puzzle/adventuring aspects of the game were what sold me on the game itself. And not on my first playthrough but my third one as well.You are given a stick to start with that can temporarily be set on fire. You later can get a Flame Scimitar (like the stick but stronger and always on fire), the Portal Wand that can create blocks and teleport things, and a Freeze Wand. Some items have some synnergy between them that becomes useful when solving a room when you only have two items.In order to beat the game, you only require two out of three items; however, on your first playthrough, you will want to collect all three items to 100% the game. Not only would you want to do this for achievements, but after each item-boss, there are extra dungeons that teach you more in-game mechanics through smaller, harder puzzles.The only reward  worth caring about is the heart-notes for extra lives; the cards are added in for flavor, but it's the practice of familiarizing yourself with the mechanics and experimenting with your tools are the real rewards for the challenge. They're all centered on the item you bought and they're all completely optional, so the puzzles are a great method of teaching the player how to play the game better.Once you have all three items, and you think you're smart enough, you can then tackle the Master Cave. You might think these challenges begin fairly simple (for the first four or five rooms), but the later challenges will test your reflexes as much as your puzzle-solving skills, sometimes in really convuluted ways. I'll admit I had to use a guide because some solutions were so specific to the millisecond I wouldn't be able to figure it out on my own. Although the payoff for completing the twelve hardest puzzles of the game is anticlimatic (as well as the boss-fight), this part of the game will teach you skills you were not even aware of you had all the time with a given tool (or combination of the two).A complete playthrough, on a (mostly) blind run, will take you about four to seven in-game hours depending on how stubborn you are to avoid a guide. The real fun of the game comes on your next three playthroughs.A Task Against FamiliarityAs mentioned before, the game is designed for you to complete the game with two out of three items. Backtracking for the items is less tedious as you'll most likely be able to solve the professional shortcuts after the Master Cave. Navigating through the Castle with a limited amount of items is the real challenge.The game forces you to tackle certain rooms for enough loot for what you need while also figuring out how to reach the final boss-room. The final boss fight is tailored to whatever items you have, although the fight is much shorter as a result. Unfortunately, as a result of not having enough items to do everything, your playthrough from 4 to six hours goes down to less than fifteen minutes to three hours at most as a result of handicaping yourself. These shorter runs are still worthwhile because the game takes previous challenges and does a new spin on them, and some rooms are probably impossible (but you wont' know until you try), so these playthroughs are not worthless. I just wish there was some way to still 100% ALL rooms with these limitations. No run will match the first one in length or for completion, and they freel tailored for speedrunners alone. (I'm not a fan of speedrunning my games; I prefer to take my time and relax). "Eh, 3 out of 5 at best."This isn't my score of the game, but I think that line quite sums up my thoughts. The game has great potential to expand upon, but the shortcomings on the more interesting playthroughs make me hopeful for more polish from a game that is already nicely polished.

												While Ittle Dew does not match the scope of the 2-D Legend of Zelda games in scope and variety, it packs quite the punch for such a small and short game. The game takes many pages out of The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening's page book, and adds its own twist to it. The game largely does not focus on combat as much as its inspiration, The Legend of Zelda, but puts most of its focus on puzzle solving. And the puzzles are no push over either. In fact, I would wager that many of them are much more difficult than anything we generally see in a Zelda game. Ittle Dew also has a unique quirky sense of humor sprinkled throughout the game, and because of that and its satisfying gameplay is quite the charm. Many reviewers have complained that the game is too short. And it is short, coming in at about four hours just to beat the game. There is some content you can get before or after the game that may add to that gametime though if you wish. But I found little reason to do that. By the time you get towards the end of the game, Ittle Dew begins to reach its limit. Any continuation or extension of the game in any meaningful way would only drag out a good thing way too long. The only drawback that this game has is it's price, which is currently around $15. For a four hour game, $15 is a bit much and for some may not be worth it. Hopefully, we will see another game featuring Ittle Dew sometime in the near future. If it does though, hopefully it will either be longer, but with quality that this game would have lacked if it ran any longer. Or the game will be cheaper to match the low amount of game time.Ittle Dew in many ways does precisely what its title suggests in that: It'll do. But because of that, it focuses intently on a few aspects of gameplay, namely the puzzles and humor, that go above and beyond its title's suggestions and which ultimately makes it a great gem.

Posted: July 12, 2014
												A very endearing, traditional but fresh action adventure.The gameplay is very Zelda with puzzle-heavy top-down rooms and palace-like dungeons for each tool you acquire. The tools are very different from what you'll find in Zelda games, though, and there's a lot of focus on having them interact with each other - one puzzle may have you freeze a block to let it slide across that spike wall and then freeze and teleport a bomb so its detonation syncs with you lighting a brazier.Be aware that it doesn't take long to finish the game, but its replay value is high because the path through the castle is nonlinear, there's a lot of optional treasure/puzzles, and extra-hard shortcuts encourage challenge and speedruns. The limited game length also means that a lot of effort could go into each individual room - nothing feels rushed, and the puzzles use available game mechanics to their fullest potential.Ittle Dew's strongest point of the game is the irreverent yet cute, self-aware humour. Quirky enemy design, expressive hand-drawn graphics and the music support the atmosphere very well.Combat is rather basic and more about approaching strategically or outsmarting enemies than about the actual process of beating them up, but still a nice diversion between puzzles.If you care about silly dialogue, clever puzzles and exploring different routes through the same dungeon, this is for you. If you like long, linear games with a focus on combat and are a dialogue-skipper or prefer serious storylines, you're looking in the wrong place though.

I started it up expecting to hate it after a few minutes and then just let it idle for the cards, but boy was I wrong. This game is really good. Probably among the most fun puzzle game I've played. Easy 8/10. So in this game you play as an adventurer. Not much is known about your character aside from the fact that she's totally a girl. Different objects on the screen interact differently (or not at all) with each magical item. Conveniently, a local shopkeeper sells them and you're able to purchase them from him. Only, when you do, you're put into a puzzle series cave where you have to show somewhat of a mastery of the item to get out. Some of the puzzles are really solid, making you somewhat frustrated after not getting them within the first 10 tries. Of course, there's also the others that are super obvious and take maybe 1 attempt, 2 if you pressed the wrong button. Good variety and the later stages of the puzzles make you think with portals. Combat is pretty dull in the game. Though, admittedly, I totally died to a pancake out of recklessness more than a few times. Valv pls fix. You press x to do the damage, or you can be fancy and try to teleport mobs into spikes or something. The controls either weren't given out in the game (I had to press every key on my keyboard to figure out how to use the stick to attack for a while), or I totally didn't pay attention to the tutorial. There is a 2 level tutorial. Oh, I forgot to mention, the puzzles vary between push blocks into pressure plates, clear all enemies on the map, light all the things that need lighting, or burn out all the things that shouldn't be on fire. You might think that's pretty lame and hardly fun, but the quickness of the game definitely makes thing way less awful than they would be. Trust me.Aside from combat, which really isn't even a big deal because the game isn't driven to encourage you to fight everything on the map except in a few area where you need to to open a door, the only real upset with the game is how fast you can complete it. Keep in mind, I had intended to just get all the cards in the game and then back out. I was sucked in and before I knew it, I finished the game. I mean, sure, I didn't 100% it, but I cleared the final boss. I didn't expect to because a certain key item given out at the end led me to believe that there would be some other areas to access, but that wasn't the case. In my first blind run, I finished the game in three and a half hours. I mean, sure, that's actually a pretty reasonable time for a game to take in a campaign mode anyway, but I really really wanted more. I guess that's a good thing, though.So after getting here this far, you probably know that I'm going to rate this game pretty highly. I would put Antichamber and Portal above this game in terms of similar games that are more fun, but this game isn't too far behind! Easy eight out of ten. I would only dock points for not doing anything groundbreakingly new (which would push it over the top and is basically a requirement to get a 10. ♥♥♥♥ people who give every game 10s), and being exceptionally short. Though, the latter is likely not an issue because this game can be played on your phone.Oh yesyou heard meyou can play it on your phone. I would encourage anyone with even a mild interest in puzzle games to give this one a shot.

												The game took about 3 hours to complete my first run through, but it will get faster with experience, and there are even achievements for completing the game within 15 minutes as well as doing it with 3 combinations of only 2 of the 3 items.The game can be a bit frustrating at times, especially the final boss which was very little puzzle and a boatload of enemies that went on for far too long. The rest of the game on the other hand, was almost made up entirely of puzzles revolving around 3 items. A flaming sword, an ice wand, and a teleportation wand. The items can actually be aquired in any order if you know what you are doing, but it does a decent job of explaining each individually. By the end of the game, you have to use all of these items in conjuction with eachother. You can drop a teleportation block, freeze it, kick it across a spike pit, and then freeze the wall to shoot a teleportation beam that bounces back and hits yourself, sending you to where the frozen block landed. Now that probably sounds really complicated, but the way you are gradually led into single items and then combinations of two or all 3, you really get the hang of it by the end.All of the rooms reset every time you go in except doors that have unlocked, so this cancels any possibility of brining things between the rooms, which makes it easier to work out the puzzles. The levels are very well designed. I felt that it was always introducing new mechanics, concepts, and ways to use the items together. I actually never had a single instance where I got stuck to where I couldn't get out of a certain spot. Although if that were to happen, there is a reset room in the pause menu. There are no consumable items of any kind, not even potions. I feel as if carryable items aside from the sword and two wands would complicate the puzzles and the game, so it is great that they aren't there. The checkpoint system is great in my opinion. If you die, you come back in just as you entered the room, with no penalties of any kind. It's really not an RPG, its more of a sliding block and combat puzzle adventure, it is only really styled after Zelda visually and thematically.I encountered only a single glitch, and it was in the final boss stage. An enemy froze in its dying animation and stayed in place for a minute or so.Overall I think this is a quirky, enjoyable, and decently challenging puzzle game, with tons of references to zelda, and a cute/unique art style. The game felt a little unfinished in a few areas. There didn't seem to be any music at all while the conversation with the final boss was going on, and it just wasn't as fleshed out as it could have been. It's not a must-play title by any means, but it will challenge you and give you a few good laughs. The puzzles can seem daunting or even impossible at times, but I urge you to keep at it. A bit of trial and error, and you'll figure them out. If you aren't willing to take a minute and think about things, you might not have such a great time...

To do so, you usually had to solve puzzles and fight plent of bad guys.Enter Ittle Dew, keen on adventure and treasure, but not so much the saving the world stuff, she is finds herself stranded on an Island, with the only chance of leaving involving getting (i.e. stealing) an artifact from a castle for the shopkeeper.Along the way you must get (i.e. once again steal) at least two of three magic weapons with the help of the same shopkeeper (who gladly takes your cash for the favor) to solve the puzzles of the castle and surrounding area.This is a great game that doesn't take itself seriously, but is great for serious players.   You can speed run or play for completion.  There are shortcuts for those willing to do more challanging puzzles, and even alternative ways to solve the puzzles, all while Ittle's sarcastic attitude, her potion-holic assistant "tippsy" and a cast of quite insane villians keep you amused. If you expect your games to be serious and realistic, maybe you should look elsewhere, but if you like difficult puzzles and timeless classic-style gameplay, all wrapped up into a tribute to the adventure games of old, then this is definately the game for you.

												A fun little puzzle game with nice artwork.  Don't let the screenshots or heavily inspired Link to the Past aesthetic fool you though, Ittle Dew is about 98% block puzzles and 2% other stuff.  Do not go into this expecting an action-rpg or some kind of dungeon romp with the occasional puzzle.  It's all puzzles and your enjoyment of them will make or break the game for you.There are three items used in puzzles: fire sword, ice wand and portal blocks/teleportation.  This isn't anywhere as limiting as it may seem and the game's puzzle design is very tight and well-done.  Ittle Dew gets a lot of mileage with the different ways it incorporates using the tools together to solve puzzles.  I didn't realize until after I finished it that you can beat the game by only collecting two of the three items and with any combination of the two.   It adds a ton of replay value for future playthroughs.  The game also has "shortcut paths", basically hard puzzles that you can use to skip chunks of the game and beat it in less than twenty minutes if you know what to do.  Stuff like beating the game with different combos of items and the shortcut puzzles are cool mechanics/design decisions and I like to seeing them even if I don't necessary plan on ever using them myself.The cartoony art is very nice and vivid.  The UI is simple and efficient.  You don't have to walk out of a room to reset a failed puzzle, you can just hit start and hit reset room to save yourself the needless back and forth you'd find in similar games.  The game lets you know how many items are in each area and most collectible item rooms will let you know if you have the correct item to solve the puzzle so you don't spend time beating your head against the wall trying to solve a puzzle you don't have the right item for.  There's just a lot of little things the game does to make playing it a non-aggravating experience.In short, if you're down with games that heavily involve pushing blocks and solving puzzles, you'll probably have a solid time with Ittle Dew.  Just don't head into it expecting a Zelda-ish game.

												Ittle Dew is a side-splitting little top-down aventure game. This is everything that there is to love about independent game design wrapped in a convenent package, featuring familiar but creative gameplay and a big, non-linear environment to play in. Ittle Dew is worth playing through for it's wholesome comedic over tone alone, and once the appealing gameplay is mixed in, the result is an incredibly fun little romp.

												This is an unreasonably good game.  I do list a few nitpicks below, but they don't wreck the game.ProsFirst, the positive: This game is cleverly designed, adorable, and a lot of fun.  I enjoyed playing it, and I hope to see a sequel someday.  The puzzles were very well-presented, giving you opportunities to learn the tools before being thrown into a terrifying challenge.  You're always ready, but the puzzles always stretch you and I, for one, walked away feeling satisfied with my accomplishments.There are only 3 tools, and yet... the ways they're used are magnificent.  You don't have a bag of gimmicky gadgets to fumble through; instead each puzzle uses one, two or three tools in really clever ways, and I often felt brilliant when I completed them.The main game can be defeated when you have all three tools... but you don't need all three.  You can also beat the game with any combination of only two tools, which just warps my mind.  The puzzles felt so tight and so tough, and I was amazed to discover I could complete them with even less.  There's also various side dungeons where you can pick up more health, or collect optional cards.  The real reward is the feeling of victory and the wild ego boost that comes with completing them all by yourself, simply for fun.For a really steep challenge, there's also an optional master dungeon that requires all three tools and some really clever thinking.  I strongly recommend it.The characters and story are adorable and funny.  I liked them.  The animations are excellent, and I loved the look and feel of Ittle's world.  I also liked Ittle herself... she's charming, if devious.  Her little flying helper is also fun.  They do a good job of making fun of their genre, while adding a lot of their own character as well (which is more important than the parody, and done well).Cons:A few minor niggles include:-A bit of unclarity in hitboxes and figuring out whether an attack will hit.  It's not a huge deal, since combat is secondary to the puzzles and even this issue doesn't make the combat unfun at all.-On a couple occasions, the master dungeon pulled some unwarranted tricks, like requiring incredibly fast movement (down to the millisecond) to be in position in time to act or stop a block, which felt like a deviation from the formula that makes the game good (clever puzzle solving, not brutal platforming skill)But the major issue?I was intensely offended by the optional side-boss fight.  Instead of having you employ all the great tricks you've learned just to reach him, he throws ALL of that away... he is instead just a standard run & stab boss battle, and a brutally unfair one at that (I eventually gave up).  Only your sword matters; you will not use the other tools at all (trying will get you killed repeatedly).  The best strategies I've read for beating him were simply to have lots of health and be fast.  It requires incredibly tight controls, which this game doesn't have, so a lot of it is luck and cheesing bugs and quirks in the AI and movement.  This was not a good climax to the otherwise brilliantly designed master dungeon; instead it was a malicious slap in the face, and god it hurt.It still leaves me a bit grumpy, even after all these months.  >:(But does this ruin the game?  NO!  It felt anti-climactic and I did feel betrayed and put upon by the developers, but the rest of the game is so good, that this just fades into background noise in comparison.Summary9/10.  This is a fantastic game.  Yes, I'm still intensely bitter about the optional boss (RAAAAGE!!!!), but that doesn't destroy the pure, unfiltered joy that is the rest of this game.  Everything in the main game and optional dungeons, save for that side boss, is excellent.  I still look back with extreme fondness!  I'm looking forward to playing the free Halloween update soon, which was a really cool thing for them to add.

												Take the original Legend of Zelda's level design and add a lot of clever puzzles and a sprinkling of humor and you have "iTTLE DEW." No, this is not a Zelda-like RPG. And, no, it does not try to be a Zelda-like RPG. Putting the graphics aside, this is it's own unique game. The puzzles are worth the price of admission alone. They consist of pushing blocks, planting bombs, and and using your unique items to help you progress. Some of these puzzles can be quite challenging. One of the really clever things about this game is that some puzzles can be completed in different ways by using a different combination of your items. It makes for a lot of "ah ha" moments. There is also a real satisfaction in walking into a room that may seem utterly impossible only to discover the solution after reasoning things out. There are enemies to fight, akin to Zelda, but they serve more to enhance the puzzle mechanic rather than offer an action spin. With that said, it does mix things up in the puzzle department and there are collectables that can be picked up for your efforts. The only gripe i have with the game is that it is painfully short. It can be completed in a matter of minutes for more intelligent gamers out there; there is even an achievement for it. The average gamer will be able to experience most of what the game has to offer in two to three hours. The game does offer extras in terms of collectables that can be sought for completionists and a end game dungeon to really challenge your puzzle solving acumen. This can extend the game time some but over all it does leave you wanting more.

												It's a good game, but from what I saw I thought I was getting a zelda clone or arpg and it's nothing like that, this is entirely a puzzle game. As a puzzle game it's surprisingly challenging and the different mechanics work well together and lend to some interesting stages. The design of the puzzles actually reminds me a lot of Portal in how they're constructed and the lateral thinking that you have to apply sometimes (and not just because there's a portal wand in the game). However the game is pretty short, I was able to get the achievement for beating it in 3 hours on my first playthrough and I thought I was taking it slow. There's replay value in that puzzles that are easy with say the portal wand are much much harder when you try to brute force it using just the ice wand, and doing the Wanderer achievement was very difficult and at times I had to use a walkthrough which is something I never do. The collectables are entirely pointless (they even say so in the game), the bosses and combat in general is frustrating and not fun at all, and the entire game can feel shallow but there's fun to be had. I got it for nearly nothing on the humble bundle and I wouldn't recommend paying much more than $5 for it based on its length but if you like puzzle games you'll probably have a lot of fun with it. I just wish they focused more on the puzzles and took out the combat parts of it entirely, since they serve no purpose and will end up♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥you off more than anything.EDIT: I forgot one of the most important aspects for me which is linux support (if you're running on Windows you can just skip over this). This game does support linux and plays great on it compared to other ports on steam, with fully working achievements unlike say Postal 2 (which still bothers me to this day). HOWEVER the controller support is wonky. The first time I ever started the game I calibrated my controller, and everything worked perfectly. I close the game, restart it, and the controls for the analog stick are completely broken, the character will walk when I dont press anything, will go in the opposite direction of what I tell it to, and generally it's unplayable with the stick now even though it worked perfectly the first time, and recalibration did nothing to fix it. Thankfully I was able to map movement to the dpad instead which was fine, but since I'm using a ps3 controller and the dualshock 3's dpad is garbage it was pretty annoying to control like that, though everything else worked perfectly.

Ittle Dew is a game which made me realize that the Zelda-like genre of games is inherently awful and that people who like them probably only like them out of nostalgia. It claims to "boil down the classic adventure formula until there is only fun left" but I've realized no amount of boiling will get rid of the BS that goes straight to the very bones of this game and games in similar veins. I understand that there is a level of subjectivity involved, that maybe this genre is just not "for me," but this is my review based on my experience of the game, most of which is negative. Mechanically, nearly everything about this game is bad. It does not modernize or simplify ("boil down" to use the devs' words) any of the frustrations of old school Zelda, it literally rips the most infuriating aspects of those games out and reskins them. It manages to even add some of its own terrible ideas to the pile of garbage. I don't usually do this but I listed them down.1) Your weapon attack has no arc at all. You literally cannot damage something that is right next to you but diagonal despite  the sword having a visual arc and enemies being able to knock into you and kill you like every game. This isn't Final Fantasy Tactics, I don't understand what the problem is.2) The hearts mechanic. It's so pointless to make your HP into collectibles, I don't understand why you would even bother when there's nothing to gain from killing enemies that aren't linked to puzzles. You're more likely to lose hearts than gain them given how your attacks are bound to the four cardinal directions whilst enemies fill the rooms and spam them with projectiles and fast moving bodies. Then when you die, you just gain back all your hearts anyway. And this is a game that encourages speed running. It literally does this just to emulate Zelda, there's absolutely no mechanical reason for the game to have this archaic system.3) Respawning enemies. Again, just run past everything because even if you kill anything it only serves as a removal of a distraction anyway.4) Respawning enemies in puzzle rooms.  5) Undefeatable instant kill enemies. Yup, they stole Wallmasters. The most garbage enemy in all of the Zelda franchise and you decided to emulate that.6) UNDEFEATABLE INSTANT KILL ENEMIES IN PUZZLE ROOMS. Just go to hell and stay there, please.7) Puzzle bosses that have to be hit more than once. It's a puzzle right? The same puzzle three times over doesn't make it more difficult, it just makes it tedious.8) Dexterity tests. This is where I finally drew the line. I was having trouble with a puzzle in the Master Cave and finally gave in and looked up the solution and as it turned out the solution involved pushing a dozen buttons in the correct order in a very small window of time, which the game asks you for nowhere else. Someone asked about the same puzzle on the front page of the forums at the time of this review, and the devs literally reply "Sorry not sorry." Are you kidding me.I'll give them props on two fronts: they don't make any of the collectibles missable despite having branching dungeon designs, and the worst parts of the game are optional. In fact, a lot of the game seems to be optional. Kind of makes me think they were aware that people would want to skip playing most of it.I'm being mean. This is probably a really good game for the genre, definitely compared to most of Steam. I also genuinely love the art style. But as I said at the start, I realized that this genre as a whole is just bad, the aspects of it that are considered its trademarks add nothing but artificial difficulties to a game which doesn't have a strong core of anything. If it's about the puzzles, why have all the enemies distracting you from them? If it's about beating things up or performing pro gamer moves, why are the mechanics all so wanky? It can't be about story, there's no story barring some snarky jabs at its predecessors.Games of this breed of "action-adventure", a kind of mix and match of everything, belong to another time period. Having a modern version just highlights how badly the ideas have aged with time and how the genre doesn't hold up without quality of living adjustments that other games have evolved over time. So the thing that I gained the most out of playing this game is an acute awareness that I don't actually like games like this.

												Ittle Dew is an action-adventure game heavily inspired by the Zelda games with heavy emphasis on replayability and speed-running. Mechanically, Ittle Dew works just about as well as you'd expect. You can walk around, hit enemies, but the real fun comes from the various puzzles. Like a Zelda game, Ittle Dew has an assortment of items that you'll utilize to solve puzzles. However, unlike a Zelda game, where you'll usually find yourself with 7-8 unique items, Ittle Dew only has. This isn't a major issue, for two reasons. Ittle Dew is a shorter game than Zelda games, and two the way that item's works together creates a large amount of replayabilty, due the game's design allowing for puzzles to be solved in multiple different ways. Ittle Dew's three items are a fire sword, which should be fairly self-explanatory, you hit things and light them on fire, a Portal Wand, which allows you to create blocks and teleport objects around and a Ice Wand which allows you to freeze objects. A large portion of the games puzzles are solvable in multiple different ways using any number of the game's items. Even beating the game only requires 2/3 of the items, this encourages exploration in the game world and experimentation with the game's mechanics as you figure out how to get to the end with a limited toolset, and I found doing so to be very compelling. There is also a fair amount of optional content, from hidden collectibles that require optional puzzles to be found, to a couple of optional dungeons. Competetive players will also enjoy trying to figure out optimal routes through the game in order to beat the game quickly.While I can prise Ittle Dew puzzle solving mechanics and overall design, it's not a perfect game. There's some combat throughout Ittle Dew, and frankly it's not very fun. More often than not, I found that having to kill the enemies in a room detracted from the fun puzzles that I should be solving in the room. There's also bosses, but they're mostly one-trick ponies. You'll figure out how to defeat them quite quickly, and they rarely pose a threat. The combat is a minor part of the game, but I can't help but think it could of been more deeply intergrated into the best parts of the game, the puzzle solving.

What sets Ittle Dew apart from Nintendo's classic franchise are a willingness to make fun of itself and extremely streamlined gameplay. It's so streamlined, in fact, that you can easily beat the game in only a handful of hours. There is a deck of character cards scattered throughout the world that could potentially extend your play time, but they aren't very rewarding to collect. Plus if you wait until you are fully equipped, many of these optional puzzles are easier than they were intended to be. Speaking of equipment, Ittle Dew's arsenal would leave Link green with envy. The portal wand especially introduces some very unique puzzles that elevate the game above standard-fare LoZ block pushing and flip switching. There's still plenty of that, but the game is always aware of its source material and freely pokes fun of it. The first time I picked a heart up off the ground, I nearly fell out of my chair laughing. From the irreverent sense of humor to the squiggly hand drawn graphics, Ittle Dew is a charming game that holds its own against its apparent competitor.

												Traditional Zelda is a style of gameplay that is near and dear to many people. The top down adventure makes for some creative puzzle situations and hugely detailed maps. After many years of tinkering with the formula, Nintendo is finally returning to their heritage with The Legend of Zelda: A Link Between Worlds.What are gamers to do in the meantime, though? If one is not a fan of the 3D games or the DS titles, what kind of game will fill the void? Enter Ittle Dew, a top down adventure game from indie dev Ludosity. What the game lacks in innovative puzzle and world design, it more than makes up for with charm and game feel.The plotline for Ittle Dew is incredibly simple. Your character washes up on the shore of an island and wants to get off. The caretaker of a shop will build you a raft as long as you go through some dungeons he has set up. You also need to pay him for the items he sells, so there is a main hub dungeon that will let you accrue some cash.This is probably the weakest element of the game. While the original Zelda game did not really possess a story of any kind, forgoing a narrative in today’s age is a curious decision. One can personally believe that gameplay speaks above all else, but without a strong desire to continue, some gamers may not even be bother to check Ittle Dew out.Thankfully, the puzzle designs in Ittle Dew are fairly strong. Stripping down the Zelda formula to its basics, Ittle Dew gives players very limited commands to deal with. Controls are essentially walking with the joystick, the four face buttons used for specific items and two shoulders buttons for a map and hint screen.The hint screen is very nicely done, too. Instead of spelling out solutions or talking in cryptic riddles, the game uses the humorous character of Tippsie to lightly insult the player while giving some key hints. Things like, “You’ll only need your fire sword for this room,” are better tests of skill than detailing exactly where to swing your item.The specific items collected are a teleport rod, a fire sword and an ice rod. In an interesting twist, there is no proper order of progression in the game. The best aspect of is how non-linear the design is. Upon completing the journey, I was under the belief that any player would have to acquire all three of the weapons to finish their quest. That actually isn’t the case. Some of the dungeons even have shortcuts direct to the boss rooms.Along with shortcuts and paths for skipping items, the game also has hidden dungeons for collecting extra health and cards. The cards don’t really offer any purpose to the game, but their rooms have some insidiously obtuse puzzle designs. I was stumped in one room for a solid 20 minutes before stumbling upon the answer.When you are transported to any dungeon for a specific item, you only need your wits to get through. No puzzles require another objects or skills you do not possess. This alleviates a lot of frustration from the proceedings.There really isn’t much in the way of challenge, however. If you die, the game simply restarts you in the exact same room with full health. Other than how the sword’s arc doesn’t fully surround your character, the only time one will get annoyed is when they cannot solve a puzzle quickly.A good mention must go to the writing behind Ittle Dew. Everything is very self-referential and parody laden. Genre tropes like collecting hearts and destroying pots all make some kind of appearance. Even the nonsensical nature of enemy placement gets mentioned for being so pointless.Your main character revels in eating hearts and even wishes to just smack things around. The bosses utter some ridiculously incomprehensible catch phrases and then admit to not even knowing what they were talking about. One cannot help but crack a smile while playing.Even the ending is funny. While a rather obvious plot twist occurs, when the final battle comes to a close, the game pokes fun at how most final bosses just kind of give up or don’t take a more obvious approach.Sadly, while Ittle Dew might be great at questioning why adventure games follow specific mechanics, the game really does nothing to spice them up. One shouldn’t be displeased with a fairly high quality Zelda-like game, but a lack of innovation really does hurt the final product.There are some texture designs on the world map that are misleading, as well. For the most part, you cannot walk behind any of the trees in the game. Some of the hidden dungeons are behind them, though. Enemies also disappear behind the trees and are completely invisible to the player.For that matter, the world map doesn’t really serve any purpose other than to move you from point A to point B. Hiding extraneous items behind puzzles is a great incentive for replay value, but giving players some other reason to explore would go a long way to creating a believable world.There is a bonus dungeon hidden in the fields. This acts as the penultimate test of your skills, requiring every item in the game to fully complete. There are 12 rooms and each one gets progressively more challenging in skill. This serves as a nice little bonus to an otherwise very short game.To sum everything up, while Ittle Dew might not be the second coming of adventure gaming or a masterpiece of epic proportions, the game provides plenty of wit and humor along with some decently mind bending puzzles. The game also controls nicely.For $14, one could do much worse. Ludosity certainly does not get points for creativity, but their craftsmanship is noble. This game may not be Zelda, but Ittle Dew. (7/10)

												Ittle Dew is an action-adventure game heavily inspired by the Zelda games with heavy emphasis on replayability and speed-running. Mechanically, Ittle Dew works just about as well as you'd expect. You can walk around, hit enemies, but the real fun comes from the various puzzles. Like a Zelda game, Ittle Dew has an assortment of items that you'll utilize to solve puzzles. However, unlike a Zelda game, where you'll usually find yourself with 7-8 unique items, Ittle Dew only has. This isn't a major issue, for two reasons. Ittle Dew is a shorter game than Zelda games, and two the way that item's works together creates a large amount of replayabilty, due the game's design allowing for puzzles to be solved in multiple different ways. Ittle Dew's three items are a fire sword, which should be fairly self-explanatory, you hit things and light them on fire, a Portal Wand, which allows you to create blocks and teleport objects around and a Ice Wand which allows you to freeze objects. A large portion of the games puzzles are solvable in multiple different ways using any number of the game's items. Even beating the game only requires 2/3 of the items, this encourages exploration in the game world and experimentation with the game's mechanics as you figure out how to get to the end with a limited toolset, and I found doing so to be very compelling. There is also a fair amount of optional content, from hidden collectibles that require optional puzzles to be found, to a couple of optional dungeons. Competetive players will also enjoy trying to figure out optimal routes through the game in order to beat the game quickly.While I can prise Ittle Dew puzzle solving mechanics and overall design, it's not a perfect game. There's some combat throughout Ittle Dew, and frankly it's not very fun. More often than not, I found that having to kill the enemies in a room detracted from the fun puzzles that I should be solving in the room. There's also bosses, but they're mostly one-trick ponies. You'll figure out how to defeat them quite quickly, and they rarely pose a threat. The combat is a minor part of the game, but I can't help but think it could of been more deeply intergrated into the best parts of the game, the puzzle solving.

It's not a big enough flaw to really detract from the overall experience, though.The main game will probably only run you 3-4 hours by itself, including all the extras, but replaying is worth it even if you're not achievement hunting since it does change the game quite a good bit. 												so like there's like a game series called "The Legend of Zelda" that you might have heard of and this game is basically a parody of that, and it's also actually really goodAfter crashing their makeshift raft into an island (like a certain other game), hotblooded adventuress Ittle Dew and her potion-chugging sidekick Tippsie set out to rob the island's castle of an artifact, which they need to give to the local shopkeeper so that he'll carve them another raft to leave the island with. It's an entirely lighthearted affair filled with charming characters, whimsical creatures, and colorful sights to behold, and the writing, while a bit too self-aware at times, does a good job at poking fun at the conventions of a typical top-down adventure.Gameplay, as should be clear by now, is like a condensed 2D Zelda. There's a small overworld to explore with caves to spelunk, three main dungeons, two bonus dungeons, and the island's castle, a sprawling, two-story locale which Ittle can only conquer in multiple trips, somewhat like the Tower of Spirits in Spirit Tracks. A variety of enemies roam the island, though it's usually not necessary to kill them because they can only drop hearts, and there are boss battles at the end of each dungeon, including one of the best bonus bosses ever conceived. Treasure comes in the form of Paper Scraps (Heart Pieces), Collectible Cards, and Lunch Money, which Ittle can use at the shop to buy the game's three weapons.What is particularly interesting about the game is how it offers a lot of choices. The main dungeons can be completed in any order, and they as well as the castle have multiple paths to take through them, the shorter ones — "Professional Shortcuts" — being tougher to traverse. Astoundingly, the adventure can be finished with either all weapons or any combination of two of them, meaning there are four different ways to beat the game; the game even records players' best times for each combination! Of course, a Zelda parody wouldn't be complete without puzzles. There are TONS of puzzles in this game, involving familiar concepts like block pushing, switches, mirrors and the like. The mandatory ones generally don't require too much thought, but the aforementioned Professional Shortcuts as well as the overworld caves contain puzzles that tended to take me a good five minutes to solve. One of the bonus dungeons, the Master Cave, is made of twelve incredibly difficult puzzles that really stretched the limits on how Ittle's weapons could interact with each other and the environment; some of them were so devious that I resorted to a guide and I was truly flabbergasted by their solutions. Suffice to say, the puzzles were the highlight of the game for me.The only iffy part about the gameplay is the combat, specifically Ittle's basic attack. In most 2D Zelda titles, Link swings his sword in a wide arc, but Ittle only swings in a short line directly in front of her. There were several occasions where I would attack only to miss due to the small hitbox, which usually resulted in me taking damage. Thankfully, enemies aren't that tough to take down regardless, and dying only sends Ittle back to the start of the room.If you haven't watched the trailer for the game on its store page yet, you should do so now because the graphical style of the game is delightful. In addition to being bright and vibrant, the game uses squiggly outlines for characters and moving objects; it reminds me a lot of Ed, Edd n Eddy, which is basically my favorite cartoon to this day. The music, while not as notable, is still pretty good and relaxing.Overall, Ittle Dew provides a surprising amount of pure fun for its scale and price. I clocked in around six hours my first playthrough and I'm already considering going through the game again with one of the two-weapon routes. Highly recommended.

												This may look like a Zelda clone (and it is), but it is so much more than that. Sure, you have the usual mechanics of hacking and slashing monsters of increasing difficulty, you have powerups that let you solve harder puzzles, you have dungeons with bosses that are defeated by your most recent powerup, you have even the same kind of 2-D world, even down to the platforms and bridges. You've even got the same sliding of boxes to unlock doors and using bombs to unlock hidden passageways. But does Link get to MAKE his own boxes? Does he get to warp around within a single room of a dungeon? No, but Ittle Dew does (I think that's her name. Otherwise the title makes absolutely no sense and is completely arbitrary).The main difference between this and Zelda is that there is much more block moving, as this is the main mechanic. You have four main powerups (fiery sword to light things on fire and break ice, portal blocks that act as weights, portal wand that targets things and sends them through where your portals are, and an ice wand that freezes blocks for easy pushing and douses flames.) The puzzles are based on combining all of these weapons to traverse a very Zelda-like dungeon. The difficulty increases as they put you in rooms that are supposed to be solvable but without explaining additional things that you can do with the powerups. (e.g. if you shoot ice on a wall, it makes it reflective, which means you can zap yourself with the portal gun. Took me a loooooong time to figure that out, and it was by accident.)Ittle Dew also has some good meta-humor. It knows it's a Zelda clone, and has fun with it by poking at the various tropes along the way. For example, enemies drop hearts, which replenish your health, but they're actually fleshy hearts that flop to the ground with a sickening squelch, and the character actually eats them like an apple. There's a sidekick animal that is called Tippsie that always looks drunk on whine (though, you can see it's actually health potions).It's not very long, so don't expect Zelda length playtime. Mine was a few hours, mostly because I spent a long time experimenting in just a few dungeons that were giving me trouble for dozens of minutes, whereas the average dungeon took about 2 minutes. The final boss is also a doozy, but mostly because there are 7 stages and it's not clear what you have to do. Fortunately, there are checkpoints after every stage for the boss, and in normal levels, you just go back to the nearest door (not the entrance to the dungeon, as in Zelda, a plus for Ittle Dew!)Overall, I enjoyed it. Probably won't play it again, although there are "Professional shortcuts" scattered all around for repeat players who already know some of the advanced move combinations and want to speedrun through. I think for under $5 it's worth it. I got it in a Humble Bundle with, like, six other games, so I definitely got my money's worth in that case. Buy it on sale, especially if you like puzzle games or Zelda.

												A masterful parody of the 2D Legend of Zelda games, ittle Dew (lowercase i) takes the well-known item-based puzzle solving of the series and polishes it to a mirror shine, wrapped up in a cheerful and smoothly-animated art style, while layering on enjoyable helpings of wry wit as it pokes fun at traditional video game conventions.  Who keeps putting hearts into rocks, anyways?ittle Dew never wastes time and is built as tight as a drum.  There’s no sprawling overworld, no overly dramatic plot, and no tedious filler; it gets in, delivers the puzzles, and gets out before wearing out its welcome.  The game is comprised of three short item dungeons (which can be completed in any order), a dozen or so optional puzzle rooms, and a central non-linear castle that is revisited multiple times as the player gains more items.  A first run through the game is a casual five hours (more if going for all the secrets), and optional second-run challenges are also available for the minimalist and speedrunning players.The puzzles are a masterwork in this game, relying only on simple tasks (i.e. push a block onto a button) with simple rules (i.e. ice blocks slide until they hit something) that are easy to understand but take careful planning to execute.  Puzzles squeeze every bit of use out of all the items and mechanics presented; rarely will a player encounter the same type of puzzle twice, keeping the game fresh and interesting.  However, a warning:  while the game does give vague hints, some of the more complex item mechanics are never explicitly explained, occasionally leading to seemingly impossible tasks until trial and error leads to a eureka moment.  Fortunately, the worst of these are confined to the Master Dungeon, an optional end-game challenge for people who LIKE impossible tasks.If any nitpick could be made of the game, it would be that the enemies just feel sort of “there”; a necessary construct of the game’s Legend of Zelda roots, but ultimately little more than an annoyance that detract from the puzzle-solving focus of the game.  Common baddies move slowly, deal low damage, and are easily dispatched, while the three item dungeon bosses are largely uninspired, requiring simple puzzles to be solved while dodging their predictable attacks.  The final boss fortunately bucks this trend and is a frantic and satisfying exclamation point to the game.
