												An absolute blast, I loved every second. That said, everyone here has already sung its praises. I like to talk about game scripts and writing. So if you're looking for a full review, everyone else here has got a pretty good handle on what's good and bad about the game. I wanna talk about its writing.Played it just coming off of Yooka Laylee, which had one of the worst scripts I've ever encountered in a game, but Ittle Dew is comparably comedic, childish and meta-oriented, with 4th-wall breaking jokes coming out of sardonic, goofy characters. The degree to which Ittle Dew trounces Yooka Laylee in its execution, however, is startling.Ittle Dew's writing has three things going for it that make the script not just lovable and silly, but exceptional:-A clever Double Act-Unobtrusiveness-A well-thought out balance of cynicism and heart.A good Double Act is always based on the chemistry between two disparate characters. Abbott and Costello: A no-nonsense straight-man and a clowny, intentionally-frustrating goof. The reason they bounce off each other is because they can create increasing comedic energy from the simple act of interaction.Straight man says a baseline for Goof to comment upon, which straight-man replies to with frustration, which goof replies to with knowing snark and back and forth, a consistent volley of energy that takes a decent amount of time to grow old because neither of characters ever venture into 'unlikeable'.This disparate natures of Ittle and Tippsie are naive, curious energy and sarcastic, exhausted wit. Ittle can respond with curiosity, to which Tippsie responds with cynical resentment, to which Ittle responds with frustrated surprise, to which Tippsie responds with sarcastic acknowledgement, which is a funny volley over and over again, and because they're both characters who are, if not fleshed out, then at least well-established and full of interesting, fun characteristics.As for unobtrusiveness: Ittle Dew's dialogue has a habit of appearing when a new enemy or concept is introduced and right before boss battles. Exceptions are rare. This means that dialogue only appears distinctly at moments when more information would be desirable and, very importantly, only while the game is continuing to be interesting. In the middle of a slow area, where frustration is high and concentration/patience is important, there is a 0% chance of dialogue interrupting anything or presenting itself as a time-waster.Lastly: the game is very meta, but never at its own expense. It's a game who's storyline is "We've arrived on Video Game Island, I wonder what's in store for us", and while it makes a few cracks at typical genre conventions, it never accuses itself of not being fun (something that Yooka Laylee did fairly and unfortunately often), it takes as gospel the fact that the player has shown up to have fun and has a love for the genre, and thus mirrors the player's enthusiasm by taking loving jabs and a genuine enthusiasm for the premise and world and gameplay.The ending is character-oriented, which may seem like a weird choice in a plot that's essentially non-existent, until you realize that without the formality of plot, the things we've grown to love over the game's runtime are the gameplay itself and the characters who were enjoying it.It's a delightful game with a delightful story and it doesn't need to be any more than that. Hearty recommend.

Posted: March 2
												Very fun puzzle game that never takes itself too seriously, and the Zelda inspired gameplay is boiled down to simple puzzles and adventuring and a few bits of cute flavor here and there. A lot of the main game puzzles aren't too difficult especially since they're usually designed around 2 of the 3 items you can obtain within the game, and using all 3 items makes most of the puzzles trivial. Where the main game really shines is that you can choose to completely ignore the 3rd item and try to finish the game with 2 items, resulting in different puzzle scenarios and pathways you can take.The only problem that annoys me about this game though, is that some of the hardest puzzles require you to have quick reflexes and some luck in order for you to finish them. Fortunately, most of those puzzles are extra challenges and do not stand between you and the final boss.

												Four out of Five Stars.Very enjoyable ittle game. It is well written, self aware and inventive. The puzzles are well designed and the tools that they give you feel genuinely unique. The game does an excellent job of showing you puzzles that you can't solve yet. Then, sending you to a tutorial area, teaching you the skills to solve the puzzle, and then putting you back in the world to use those skills to tackle the problems. Only major problem is performance. The game frequently drops frames and slows down, which is not acceptable, considering the graphics and AI are modest. Otherwise, fantastic.
